i want to be able share a file in a way so that i can get a link that points _directly_ to 
that file.

using such a link, a shared image could be displayed in a webpage by putting the 
link in the src attribute of a img html tag.

using such a link, a file would be directly downloaded if used with curl or wget.

using such a link in the open file dialog in kde, that file would be opened in any 
application.

these objectives can all be achieved by adding "&download" to the default share link.

here is a link to a pdf file on my owncloud server that i want to share with you:
http://owncloud.alweb.dk/public.php?service=files&file=%2fanders%2ffiles%2fprint
1.pdf

now try opening that with okular - you can't. try downloading it with wget: you get 
html text, not the pdf file.

add "&download" to the link, like here: 
http://owncloud.alweb.dk/public.php?service=files&file=%2fanders%2ffiles%2fprint
1.pdf&download

heureka - now it works as it should.

i think direct access - download - should be the default behavior, or at the very least a 
direct link should be offered alongside the fake link that is currently the default. or, 
if you even refuse that, provide the user with information about how to fix the link, on 
the share popup in the file application.
